qas.question: How were the appointments to the Order of the British Empire made?

answers.text: nomination of the self-governing Dominions of the Empire, the Viceroy of India, and the colonial governors

qas.question: What evolved as the Commonwealth nominations continued?
What remained the head of state of the British Empire?
Why did the oversea nominations discontinue?

answers.text: Order of Australia, the Order of Canada, and the New Zealand Order of Merit

context: Appointments to the Order of the British Empire were at first made on the <a0_0>nomination of the self-governing Dominions of the Empire, the Viceroy of India, and the colonial governors<a0_0/>, as well as on nominations from within the United Kingdom. As the <a1_0>Empire<a1_0/> evolved into the Commonwealth, nominations continued to come from the Commonwealth realms, in which <a2_0>the monarch<a2_0/> remained head of state. These overseas nominations have been discontinued in realms that have <a3_0>established their own Orders<a3_0/>—such as the <a4_0>Order of Australia, the Order of Canada, and the New Zealand Order of Merit<a4_0/>—but members of the Order are still appointed in the British Overseas Territories.
